title: SB 127
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature acknowledges that many areas in California are disproportionately affected by drought due to heavy reliance on groundwater from basins in overdraft or contaminated. Many areas in California are heavily impacted by drought due to reliance on overdrafted or contaminated groundwater. State grant and loan programs help communities with water needs, but individual homeowners with groundwater wells lack financial assistance for vital water supply and quality improvements. The program created by this act aims to provide low-interest loans, grants, or both to individual homeowners for safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment. This includes actions like digging deeper wells, improving existing wells, addressing water contaminants, or connecting to a local water system. Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code establishes a Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program to provide low-interest loans and grants for various purposes such as extending service lines, connecting to water systems, and closing abandoned septic tanks and wells for health and safety reasons. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program offers assistance for connecting to water systems, closing abandoned septic tanks and wells, deepening or improving groundwater wells, and installing water treatment systems if needed. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program provides assistance for connecting to water systems, closing abandoned septic tanks and wells, deepening or improving groundwater wells, and installing water treatment systems if necessary. The board may adopt regulations to carry out the program's purposes. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is created in the State Treasury for the program's purposes. The board can adopt regulations without following certain rulemaking requirements. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is established in the State Treasury for program purposes. Moneys in the fund can be used by the board upon legislative appropriation. Eligible loan applicants must meet specific criteria. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund in the State Treasury can be used for program purposes. Repaid moneys from grants or loans, along with interest payments, are included. Eligible loan applicants must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, and be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders. An eligible loan applicant must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders at reasonable terms, lack personal resources for improvements, and demonstrate an ability to repay the loan. Loan recipients must be unable to obtain financial assistance at reasonable terms from private lenders and lack personal resources for improvements. They must also demonstrate an ability to repay the loan, which can be satisfied by having a cosigner. The loan will be secured by a mortgage on the residence and repaid within 20 years with an interest rate not exceeding 1 percent. Homeowner's insurance must be maintained on the residence while the loan balance is outstanding. The board may contract with a private financial institution to provide loans under certain criteria, including having a household income below 60% of the statewide median, owning the residence, and being unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders. An eligible applicant for a grant must have a household income 60% or less of the statewide median, own the residence, and be unable to get financial assistance from private lenders. Recipients must repay the grant if they sell the residence within five years or return any unused funds to the board. SEC. 3. Ten million dollars ($10,000,000) is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund. SEC. 4. This act is an urgency statute for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety and shall go into immediate effect. Ten million dollars is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund to provide eligible households with access to safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment during California's prolonged drought. This act is an urgency statute for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety. The act aims to provide eligible households with access to safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment during California's drought. It defines a "water project" as one funded by bonds from the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. Section 21168.6.7 of the Public Resources Code defines a "water project" as one funded by bonds from the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. The procedures established in this section apply to actions challenging the certification of environmental impact reports or approvals for water projects. The Judicial Council must adopt a rule of court by July 1, 2016, to establish procedures for resolving actions challenging the certification of environmental impact reports for water projects within 270 days. Environmental impact reports for water projects must include a notice in at least 12-point type. The final environmental impact report for a water project must include a notice in not less than 12-point type stating that certain comments filed after the public comment period for the draft EIR may not be considered. Judicial actions challenging the certification of the EIR or project approval are subject to specific procedures outlined in the Public Resources Code. The draft and final environmental impact reports must include the full text of specific sections. The lead agency must conduct an informational workshop after releasing the draft report and hold a public hearing before the comment period ends. A transcript of the hearing will be included in the final report. Within five days after the public comment period, a commenter on the draft environmental impact report can request nonbinding mediation. The mediation must involve the lead agency, applicant, and all commenters who requested it, and must be completed within 35 days after the comment period. The request for mediation should specify the areas of dispute to be mediated. The lead agency selects mediators with expertise in land use and environmental law or science for mediation requested by commenters. The applicant covers the mediation costs, and sessions are held for each area of dispute identified. (D)A mediation session shall be conducted on each area of dispute with the parties requesting mediation. The lead agency must adopt any agreed-upon measures as a condition of approval. Written comments submitted after the public comment period will only be considered if they address specific issues. The lead agency does not have to consider comments submitted after the public comment period, unless they address new issues raised in the response to comments, new information released by the public agency, or changes made to the project after the comment period. The lead agency must consider new issues raised in response to comments, new information released by the public agency, changes to the project post-comment period, and proposed conditions or mitigation measures. The lead agency must file required notices within five days after project approval, including proposed conditions, mitigation measures, new information not known during public comment period. The lead agency must file required notices within five days after project approval, including proposed conditions, mitigation measures, and new information not known during the public comment period. The lead agency is responsible for preparing and certifying the record of proceedings, with the applicant covering all costs. The lead agency must make the draft environmental impact report and related documents available to the public in an electronic format within three business days of release. Any additional documents related to the report must be accessible within five business days of preparation or receipt by the lead agency. The lead agency is required to make the draft environmental impact report and related documents available in an electronic format within three business days of release. Copyright protected documents not prepared specifically for the project do not need to be electronically accessible, but an index of these documents must be available electronically by the release of the draft report or within five business days if received later. The index should specify where hardcopies of the copyrighted materials can be reviewed by the public. The lead agency must convert non-electronic comments into electronic format within seven days and make them available to the public. Comments not considered by the lead agency do not need to be included in the record of proceedings. Within five days of filing the required notice, the lead agency must certify and provide an electronic copy of the proceedings record to a party upon request. A reasonable fee may be charged for the copy. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. (9) Disputes over the record's content will be resolved by the superior court, with parties filing a motion to augment the record if necessary. (10) The contents of the record shall follow guidelines in Section 21167.6. (9) Any dispute over the record of proceedings will be resolved by the superior court, with parties filing a motion to augment the record if needed. (10) The contents of the record shall adhere to guidelines in Section 21167.6. In granting relief, the court shall not halt the construction or operation of a water project unless there is an imminent threat to public health and safety. In granting relief in an action brought pursuant to this division, the court shall not stay or enjoin the construction or operation of a water project unless there is an imminent threat to public health and safety or unforeseen important Native American artifacts or historical, archaeological, or ecological values at the water project site. The court will only enjoin specific activities of a water project if they pose a threat to public health, Native American artifacts, or important historical, archaeological, or ecological values. Any challenge to a project approval decision must follow Chapter 6 requirements. An action to challenge a project approval decision must adhere to Chapter 6 requirements. No reimbursement is necessary for this act as local agencies can generate funds to cover mandated services.
